Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Medium: Collaborative Research: Crafting a Human-Centric Environment to Support Human Health Needs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers and providers alike are recognizing that human-centric smart environments can provide health monitoring services and support aging in place through adaptive interventions. The need for the development of such technologies is underscored by the aging of the population, the cost of formal health care, and the importance that individuals place on remaining independent in their own homes. The goal of this project is to design, implement, and evaluate in-home techniques for generating reports of activities and social interactions that are useful for monitoring well being and for automating intervention strategies for persons with dementia. The plan is to design machine learning techniques that make effective use of sensor data to perform automated activity monitoring and prompting-based interventions that are beneficial for the residents as well as for their caregivers and family. The environment is human-centric because it learns information about its human residents and uses this information to provide activity-aware monitoring and intervention services. By transforming everyday environments into smart environments, many older adults with cognitive and physical impairment can lead independent lives in their own homes. A key component of this project is an evaluation of the technologies in actual homes with volunteer older adults and thus will assess the technologies for acceptance with the target population.

This project addresses NSF?s Smart Health and Wellbeing goal of leveraging computational expertise leading to fundamental advances in the development of algorithms to create improvements in safe, effective, and patient-centered health and wellness services. Through design of a Gerontechnology class we are training students to design and use these technologies. This effort includes REU and IGERT students in the research project, which involves students from underrepresented groups in this multidisciplinary, collaborative effort. To facility community-wide use, comparison and collaboration, all of our datasets, tools, and course materials will be disseminated from our project web page.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this SHB project was to leverage fundamental advances in algorithms and models for creating effective, secure, and patient-centered health and wellness management services. The underlying idea is to transform everyday environments into smart environments, such that older adults with cognitive and physical impairment can lead independent lives in their own homes. The project led to several research innovations with broader impacts as summarized below.

 

Intellectual Merit: The SHB project resulted in the development of novel frameworks, models, algorithms and solutions for: (i) recognition of complex at-home activities of daily living and other context in sensor-based smart health environments; (ii) integration of cyber-physical-social interactions of human for monitoring wellness and automating intervention strategies for better healthcare; (iii) characterizing information and context quality in pervasive computing and crowdsensing platforms with applications to health care; and (iv) context-aware privacy preservation and integrity of health data. These objectives were achieved due to the following algorithmic and architectural innovations: (a) resource-efficient algorithms for data gathering, fusion and analytics in sensor-based smart healthcare and pervasive computing environments integrated with edge computing capabilities; (b) advanced modeling and analysis of learning, intelligence building, inferencing, and decision making schemes; (c) secure and trustworthy frameworks for preserving data privacy, authenticity, and integrity in crowdsourced smart healthcare applications; and (d) design of smart chair and IoT-enabled wearable platforms to evaluate the proposed frameworks and solutions with the help of real patient study in a hospital, thereby assessing their physical and cognitive health conditions. The proposed solutions are based on a rich set of theoretical and practical design principles, grounded in uncertainty reasoning, advanced algorithms, information theory, game theory, graph theory, trust models, reputation and incentive models. The research resulted in more than two dozen publications in top-tier venues such as: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, ACM Transactions on Networks, ACM/IEEE Transactions on Networking, IEEE Transactions on Service Computing, Pervasive and Mobile Computing, IEEE Computer, and so on.

 

Broader Impacts: This SHB project has had tremendous impacts in terms of (i) student training including undergraduates and women, (ii) dissemination via keynote talks at international conferences and publications in top-tier journals and conferences, (iii) outreach to a county hospital in rural Missouri to study patients with cognitive impairment such as Dementia and Alzheimer’s, (iv) technology transfer with potential for commercialization, and (v) inception of a startup company. More specifically, a Postdoc, three Ph.D. students (one female), one MS thesis student, and nine REU students (three women and two underrepresented minority) were trained through this project. Two PhD students and one MS thesis student have completed their degrees. Motivated by the research experience, three REU students joined the PhD program. The Postdoc was mentored and trained to take up entrepreneurship career. The project led to an I-Corps project and a NSF STTR-Phase I project, leading to the spin-off of Smart Health Beacons, LLC spearheaded by the Postdoc. One patent has already been filed and two patents are in the process of filing.
